data.name: How many e's are written when one counts up to n?  1. Chinese
data.description: This serial of katas is a fork of Project Euler Problem 17 [https://projecteuler.net/problem=17]. In different languages, people count differently. Here we look at standard Chinese (a.k.a. Mandarin) written in pinyin without tones. The numbers 0 to 10 are written as _ling_, _yi_, _er_, _san_, _si_, _wu_, _liu_, _qi_, _ba_, _jiu_, _shi_. There are no special words for any numbers from 11 to 99. To say 11 to 19, one just thinks they are 11 = 10 + 1, 12 = 10 + 2 and so on, so 11 is _shiyi_, 12 is _shi'er_, 13 is _shisan_ etc. To say 20 to 90, one just thinks they are 20 = 2 \* 10, 30 = 3 \* 10 ... so 20 is _ershi_, 30 is _sanshi_. Hence very logically 42 is _sishi'er_. Some larger numbers have their own names: * _Bai_ for 100 * _Qian_ for 1000 * _Wan_ for 10,000 * _Yi_ for 100,000,000 [Actually 100,000,000 and 1 are in different tones. Do not worry if they are mistaken. ] Though a single _er_ immediately before _bai_, _qian_, _wan_, and _yi_ is often read as _liang_ in daily spoken Chinese [e.g. 120000 _shi'erwan_, 20000 _liangwan_], in this kata __we do not consider this change__ and __regard numbers like 20000 still as _erwan_ etc.__ For example, in this kata: * 207 erbailingqi: 2 * 100 + 7. _Ling_ is inserted just because it is accustomed. * 3005 sanqianlingwu: 3 * 1000 + 5. * 12345 yiwan'erqiansanbaisishiwu: 1 \* 10,000 + 2 \* 1000 + 3 \* 100 + 4 \* 10 + 5 * 1048576 yibailing'siwanbaqianwubaiqishiliu: (1 \* 100 + 4) \* 10,000 + 8 \* 1000 + 5 \* 100 + 7 \* 10 + 6 * 299792458 eryijiuqianjiubaiqishijiuwanerqiansibaiwushiba: 2 \* 100,000,000 + (9 \* 1000 + 9 \* 100 + 7 \* 10 + 9) \* 10,000 + 2 \* 1000 + 4 \* 100 + 5 \* 10 + 8 Here comes the kata question. Write a function n_e_count_up_to(n), * where n is a __positive__ integer guaranteed not to be more than _babaiwan_, * and the expected returned value is the total number of letter 'e' in all the pinyin of numbers from 1 to n (both inclusive). Example: n\_e\_count\_up\_to(3) == 1, because writing them in a line gives _yi_, _**E**r_, _san_ ---> only one 'e' has been met. Can you think about some shortcuts to speed up the calculation? Hint: do the Chinese units for counting really make difference to the solution? Perhaps I will bring up a harder kata with larger n, not suitable for a fundamental kata. Even in this kata in C, I do not think it will finish within 12 seconds (_shi'er miao_) if every pinyin string is generated; but I am not sure, so you may try and succeed (or probably not). Thanks for your suggestions in advance.
